content: The Act titled "Voter Outreach and Turnout Expansion Act of 2003" includes provisions for same-day voter registration. The Voter Outreach and Turnout Expansion Act of 2003 allows for same-day voter registration at polling places for federal elections. If an application is received after the registration deadline, the individual will be notified and can register to vote at the polling place on the date of the election. The polling place must meet requirements under the National Voter Registration Act of 1993. Section 302(b)(2) of the Act is amended to include instructions for individuals registering to vote at the polling place under section 303(d). Each State and jurisdiction must comply with voter registration requirements on the date of the election starting January 1, 2004. SEC. 102 of the Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to allow voters to cast early and absentee ballots for any reason. Each jurisdiction administering elections for Federal office must establish early voting sites as polling places before the election date. Registered and eligible voters can cast their ballots at these sites, which will be treated like absentee ballots. The early voting sites will operate for a specified period. The jurisdiction must designate early voting sites for an election period starting no later than 22 days before the election date or when ballots are available. At least 2 days during this period must be weekend days. The number and location of these sites are determined by the jurisdiction, with a focus on practicality. The jurisdiction must designate early voting sites for an election period starting no later than 22 days before the election date. The sites must include voter registration agencies and at least 25% of the total voting systems used in all polling places. One site must be accessible for individuals with disabilities, and the geographic distribution of sites should reflect the voting distribution. The jurisdiction must establish early voting sites that reflect the geographic distribution of the voting age population. Compliance with the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is required. States cannot require a reason for requesting an absentee ballot. Amendments include a deadline for the adoption of voluntary guidance by the election assistance commission. It also includes a clerical amendment to the table of sections. SEC. 103. CLARIFICATION OF REQUIREMENT TO PERMIT INDIVIDUALS TO COMPLETE INCOMPLETE MAIL-IN VOTER REGISTRATION APPLICATIONS. Section 303(b)(4)(B) of the Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to address incomplete voter registration forms, requiring registrars to notify applicants of missing information and provide the opportunity to register at the polling place on election day if the form was received within the state deadline. The amended Section 303(b)(4)(B) of the Help America Vote Act of 2002 requires registrars to notify applicants of missing information on voter registration forms and provide the opportunity to complete the form before the election. SEC. 104. ADDITIONAL FUNDING. Amends funding amounts in the Help America Vote Act of 2002. SEC. 105. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments take effect as if included in the original Act. TITLE II--REMOVING OTHER BARRIERS TO VOTING. SEC. 201. ELECTION DAY TREATED LIKE VETERANS DAY FOR FEDERAL EMPLOYMENT. It is the sense of Congress that many Americans do not vote on Election Day due to work conflicts. Governments should work together to increase voter turnout by making Election Day a legal public holiday with full paid leave for State employees. Treating Election Day like Veterans Day for Federal employment purposes will boost voter turnout and improve access to polling places. For Federal employment purposes, the Tuesday after the first Monday in November of even-numbered years will be treated like November 11. SEC. 202. VOTING LEAVE. Employees are allowed up to 2 hours of leave (or up to 3 hours if the polling place is over 25 miles away) to vote in federal elections. The leave can be unpaid or paid, and employees must make an effort to schedule it without disrupting work operations. Taking this leave will not result in the loss of any employment benefits. Employees are entitled to leave to vote in federal elections without losing any employment benefits. Employers are prohibited from interfering with or discriminating against employees who take this leave. Employees are entitled to leave for voting in federal elections without losing benefits. The Secretary of Labor has investigative authority and enforcement powers similar to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 for employers under this subsection. In this section, the term "employer" is defined as any person engaged in commerce or industry with 25 or more employees, including successors in interest. Implementation and enforcement must comply with the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Effective date applies to this section. Effective Date: This section applies to elections after January 2004. Congress encourages states and jurisdictions to distribute sample ballots and voter education materials to registered voters before elections to prevent errors and reduce spoiled ballots.
